wikipedia_page.main: Derek Russell Davis FBPsS FRCPsych (20 April 1914 – 3 February 1993) was a British psychiatrist who served as the Norah Cooke-Hurle Professor of Mental Health at Bristol University from 1962 to 1979.

response: In 1890, William James defined psychology as "the science of mental life, both of its phenomena and their conditions."James, W. (1890). The Principles of Psychology. New York: Henry Holt. This definition enjoyed widespread currency for decades. However, this meaning was contested, notably by radical behaviorists such as John B. Watson, who in 1913 asserted that the discipline is a "natural science," the theoretical goal of which "is the prediction and control of behavior." Since James defined "psychology," the term more strongly implicates scientific experimentation.Derek Russell Davis (DRD), "psychology", in Richard L. Gregory (ed.), The Oxford Companion to the Mind, second edition; Oxford University Press, 1987/2004;  (pp. 763–764). Folk psychology refers to the understanding of ordinary people, as contrasted with that of psychology professionals, with regard to the mental states and behaviors of people.The term "folk psychology" is itself contentious: see Daniel D. Hutto & Matthew Ratcliffe (eds.), Folk Psychology Re-Assessed; Dorndrecht, the Netherlands: Springer, 2007;

Hooper's national service was spent with the Royal Air Force. Upon his discharge, Hooper enrolled at Reading University to study psychology. He obtained a PhD in psychology from King's College, Cambridge, under the direction of Derek Russell Davis.
